phenotype_entities.name: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer

assertions_made.justification: OMIM lists two distinct phenotypes with different inheritance: Fumarase deficiency (AR) and HLRCC (AD). Orphanet additionally lists hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma as a separate disease and uses the label fumaric aciduria for the AR condition.

molecular_mechanism.justification: Both AR fumarase deficiency and AD HLRCC involve loss of FH enzymatic function (biallelic deficiency in AR; tumor suppressor with reduced activity and biallelic inactivation in tumors for AD). Despite shared LOF, disease biology and clinical context differ (metabolic encephalopathy vs tumor predisposition).

phenotypic_variability.justification: AR disease is a severe neurodevelopmental/encephalopathic disorder, whereas AD HLRCC is a tumor predisposition syndrome with leiomyomas and renal cell carcinoma. Variability within HLRCC exists, but is within a tumor spectrum and distinct from the AR presentation.

mode_of_inheritance.justification: Fumarase deficiency/fumaric aciduria is autosomal recessive; HLRCC is autosomal dominant. Orphanet lists FH for hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma but MOI is not specified in the provided text.

entity_decisions.name: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer

proposed_groupings.reasoning: OMIM and GeneReviews describe AR FH deficiency; Orphanet’s 'Fumaric aciduria' refers to the same AR LOF condition. Shared mechanism and management justify lumping.

entities: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer
proposed_groupings.proposed_label: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer
proposed_groupings.reasoning: Consistently asserted as a distinct AD tumor predisposition syndrome with different phenotype and clinical management from AR FH deficiency.

overall_decision.summary_reasoning: Authoritative sources consistently present two main FH-related entities: AR fumarase deficiency/fumaric aciduria and AD HLRCC. Despite shared LOF at the gene level, they differ in inheritance, clinical presentation, and management. Orphanet additionally lists hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma for FH, but corroboration in OMIM/GeneReviews is absent in this bundle, so its relationship to HLRCC remains unclear.

top_supporting_evidence: OMIM: Gene-Phenotype Relationships – 'Fumarase deficiency 606812 AR' and 'Leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer 150800 AD'

GeneReviews: 'Fumarate hydratase (FH) deficiency results in severe neonatal and early infantile encephalopathy...' and 'Heterozygotes are at risk of developing hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer.'

Orphanet (FH page): 'Disease-causing germline mutation(s) in Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer ORPHA:523' and '... (loss of function) in Fumaric aciduria ORPHA:24' and '... in Hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma ORPHA:29072'
suggested_action_for_curator: Verify whether FH-associated hereditary pheochromocytoma-paraganglioma should be considered part of HLRCC spectrum or a separate FH-related entity based on additional sources.
Confirm mode of inheritance and clinical management distinctions for any FH-related pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma cases.
